author: Bobby Grayson
message:
feat(web): Add roadmap view and API integration (#90) * feat(roadmap): Phase 3-5 - GitHub CLI integration and sync commands (#88) * feat(roadmap): Phase 3 - GitHub CLI integration Add gh CLI wrapper for GitHub issue operations: - Create, update, close, reopen issues - Get issue details and comments - Search issues by title or label - Auto-detect repo from git remote Uses gh CLI instead of direct API to avoid token complexity. Decision Graph: Action #497 * feat: add roadmap CLI commands - Add RoadmapAction enum with init, sync, list, link, unlink, conflicts, status subcommands - Implement deciduous roadmap init - parses ROADMAP.md and adds metadata - Implement deciduous roadmap sync - bidirectional sync with GitHub Issues - Implement deciduous roadmap list - displays items with filters - Implement deciduous roadmap link/unlink - connects items to outcome nodes - Implement deciduous roadmap conflicts - shows sync conflicts - Implement deciduous roadmap status - shows sync summary - Add update_roadmap_item_github_by_title and update_roadmap_item_github_by_change_id methods - Add get_roadmap_sync_state method * feat(roadmap): address PR feedback - safer sync defaults & caching - Make --dry-run default for `roadmap sync` (use --execute to apply) - Auto-create 'roadmap' label if it doesn't exist - Add GitHub issue cache table for TUI/Web display - Cache issues locally when created during sync Addresses PR #88 feedback: 1. Cache GitHub state locally for TUI + serve + web 2. Make --dry-run default (require --execute flag) 3. Auto-create roadmap label Note: `roadmap init` idempotency to be done as separate patch release # Roadmap Board System - Part 2: GitHub Integration & CLI ## Context With the data layer in place (PR #87), we can now connect to GitHub. This PR adds: 1. **GitHub CLI wrapper** - Shell out to `gh` for issue operations 2. **Sync engine** - Bidirectional sync between ROADMAP.md and GitHub Issues 3. **CLI commands** - `deciduous roadmap init/sync/list/link` ## Why Shell Out to `gh`? We use GitHub's official CLI (`gh`) rather than the REST API because: | Approach | Pros | Cons | |----------|------|------| | `gh` CLI | No token management, uses existing auth, handles rate limiting | Requires `gh` installed | | REST API | No external dependency | Token management, rate limit handling, more code | | GraphQL API | Efficient batching | Complex, token management | **Decision**: Shell out to `gh`. Users already have it for `gh pr create`. If they don't, they get a clear error message. ## New Files ### `src/github.rs` (~400 lines) GitHub CLI wrapper with typed responses: ```rust pub struct GitHubClient { repo: Option, // "owner/repo" format } impl GitHubClient { pub fn auto_detect() -> Result; pub fn check_auth() -> Result; // Issue operations pub fn create_issue(&self, title: &str, body: &str, labels: &[&str]) -> Result; pub fn update_issue_body(&self, number: i32, body: &str) -> Result<()>; pub fn close_issue(&self, number: i32) -> Result<()>; pub fn get_issue(&self, number: i32) -> Result; // Label operations (NEW) pub fn label_exists(&self, name: &str) -> Result; pub fn create_label(&self, name: &str, description: &str, color: &str) -> Result<()>; } // Auto-create roadmap label if needed pub fn ensure_roadmap_label(client: &GitHubClient) -> Result; ``` ### CLI Commands ```bash # Initialize roadmap tracking deciduous roadmap init [--path ROADMAP.md] # Sync with GitHub (dry-run by default!) deciduous roadmap sync [--execute] [--path PATH] [--repo OWNER/REPO] # List items deciduous roadmap list [--with-issues] [--without-issues] [--section NAME] # Link to outcome deciduous roadmap link ITEM OUTCOME_ID ``` ## Feedback Discussion Summary | Question | Answer | Implementation | |----------|--------|----------------| | Cache GitHub state locally? | **Yes** - for TUI + serve + web | ✅ Added `github_issue_cache` table | | Rate limits? | OK as-is, one-time | No changes needed | | `roadmap init` idempotent? | Yes, but separate patch | Will be separate PR | | `--dry-run` default? | **Yes** | ✅ Requires `--execute` to apply | | Auto-create "roadmap" label? | **Yes** | ✅ Auto-creates on first sync | ## New: GitHub Issue Cache For TUI/Web display without hitting GitHub's API: ```sql CREATE TABLE github_issue_cache ( id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, issue_number INTEGER NOT NULL, repo TEXT NOT NULL, title TEXT NOT NULL, body TEXT, state TEXT NOT NULL, html_url TEXT NOT NULL, created_at TEXT NOT NULL, updated_at TEXT NOT NULL, cached_at TEXT NOT NULL, UNIQUE(repo, issue_number) ); ``` **Methods:** - `db.cache_github_issue(...)` - Cache/update an issue - `db.get_cached_issue(repo, number)` - Get cached issue - `db.get_cached_issues_for_repo(repo)` - All issues for a repo - `db.clear_stale_cache(max_age_hours)` - Cleanup old entries ## Sync Architecture ``` ┌─────────────────┐ │ ROADMAP.md │ │ (human edits) │ └────────┬────────┘ │ parse ▼ ┌─────────────────┐ │ SQLite │────┐ │ (roadmap_items) │ │ └────────┬────────┘ │ │ sync │ cache ▼ ▼ ┌─────────────────┐ ┌───────────────┐ │ GitHub Issues │ │ Issue Cache │ │ (team visible) │ │ (TUI/Web) │ └─────────────────┘ └───────────────┘ ``` **Default is safe**: `roadmap sync` shows what would happen without making changes. Use `--execute` to actually create issues. ## Decision Graph References | Node | Type | Description | |------|------|-------------| | #477 | decision | "Choose sync architecture" | | #478 | option | "Bidirectional sync" ← CHOSEN | | #497 | action | "Implementing Phase 3: GitHub CLI" | | #498 | outcome | "Phase 3 complete: GitHub CLI integration" | | #499 | action | "Implementing Phase 4-5: CLI + Sync" | | #500 | outcome | "Phase 4-5 complete: CLI commands with sync" | ## Test Plan - [x] `cargo build` - Compiles - [x] `cargo test` - Tests pass - [ ] Manual: `gh auth status` shows authenticated - [ ] Manual: `roadmap init` parses ROADMAP.md - [ ] Manual: `roadmap sync` (dry-run default) shows what would happen - [ ] Manual: `roadmap sync --execute` creates issues - [ ] Manual: Verify 'roadmap' label auto-created - [ ] Manual: `roadmap list --with-issues` shows linked items ## Merge Dependencies **Requires PR #87** (Data Layer) to be merged first. ## Next PR **Part 3: TUI View** will add: - `src/tui/views/roadmap.rs` - Terminal roadmap browser - Display cached issues without network calls * feat(tui): add roadmap view - Add View::Roadmap variant to app.rs - Create src/tui/views/roadmap.rs with RoadmapState - Display roadmap items with sync status indicators - Show checkbox state, GitHub issue, and outcome links - Add keyboard navigation (j/k) and refresh (r) - Wire into events.rs and ui.rs - Tab key cycles between Timeline and Roadmap views * feat(tui): refactor roadmap view with TEA architecture - Rewrite roadmap.rs with functional core (pure functions for testability) - Add Active/Completed view toggle (Shift+Tab) - Add detail panel toggle (Enter) - Add 'o' key to open GitHub issue in browser - Add 'c' key to toggle checkbox state - Update help overlay with roadmap keybindings - Add tests for all pure functions Completion criteria: checkbox_state=checked AND outcome linked AND issue closed * fix(tui): roadmap view improvements - Filter out section headers (checkbox_state=none) from item list - Fix section assignment: items belong to their ### section, not ## parent - Add grouped rendering with section headers (── Section Name ──) - Items indented under sections with proper hierarchy - Add is_section_header() and is_item_fully_synced() helpers - Add clear_roadmap_items() for refresh functionality - Add 'roadmap refresh' command to repopulate items - Update completion logic: complete if checkbox checked OR in Completed section - Add vim navigation (G/gg, Ctrl-D/U, PageUp/Down) to roadmap view - Add keyboard hints bar at bottom - Add Active/Completed tab bar at top * feat(web): add roadmap view - Create RoadmapView.tsx component - Display roadmap items with sync status indicators - Show checkbox state, GitHub issue badges, outcome links - Add filtering by section and status (all, with-issues, without-issues, completed) - Integrate with DetailPanel for outcome node viewing - Add /roadmap route to App.tsx - Add Roadmap tab to Layout navigation - Rebuild demo and embedded viewer * feat(roadmap): add Phase 8/9 - type export and completion detection - Export RoadmapItem, RoadmapSyncState, RoadmapConflict from lib.rs - Add roadmap types to bin/gen_types.rs for TypeScript generation - Add 'roadmap check' command for completion audit - Shows checkbox state, outcome link, issue closed status per item - Supports --incomplete and --complete filters - Displays summary with complete/incomplete counts - Initialize roadmap items in database after schema migration * chore(web): add roadmap types to generated schema Type-only change - updates imports in RoadmapView.tsx to use generated types from schema.ts instead of local interface. No runtime change to the built bundle. * feat(web): add roadmap API and React integration - Add GET /api/roadmap endpoint to serve.rs - Add POST /api/roadmap/checkbox endpoint for toggle - Update useGraphData hook to fetch roadmap items - Pass roadmapItems through App.tsx to RoadmapView - Rewrite RoadmapView.tsx with: - Active/Completed toggle (Tab key) - Keyboard navigation (j/k, o, c, Enter, Escape) - Click to toggle checkbox - Status message display - API integration for checkbox updates Works with both dev server and bundled viewer (deciduous serve) Bundled viewer rebuilt for GitHub Pages and deciduous serve * feat(web): align RoadmapView with TUI completion logic Updates web roadmap view to match TUI implementation: - isItemComplete: checkbox checked OR in "Completed" section - isItemFullySynced: strict 3-way (checkbox + outcome + issue) - Filter out section headers (checkbox_state === 'none') - Group items by section with section header rendering - Add vim navigation: gg (top), G (bottom) - ASCII checkboxes [x]/[ ] instead of emoji - Item index numbers like TUI row numbers - Detail panel shows both complete and sync status * style(web): modern UI redesign for RoadmapView Complete visual overhaul with polished, modern aesthetics: - Clean card design with subtle shadows and hover effects - Custom checkbox with SVG checkmark animation - Section headers with divider lines and item counts - Colored status pills (synced, in progress) - GitHub badge with icon - Refined sidebar with toggle buttons - Better keyboard hints with styled kbd elements - Improved detail panel with sync status grid - Empty states with icons and call-to-action buttons - Consistent color palette (blue/green/amber/purple) - Smooth transitions throughout * fix(web): wire up checkbox click to toggle API * fix: update checkbox state in place without page reload Use optimistic local state update when toggling checkboxes: - Add local items state that syncs from props - Update state immediately on checkbox click - Fire-and-forget API call in background - No page reload, no network fetch, instant UI response ## Summary This PR brings the roadmap board to the web interface, enabling browser-based visualization of roadmap items alongside the existing decision graph. This is **Phase 7** of the roadmap board implementation. **Part 4 of 5 in the roadmap board PR chain** (targets PR #89) ## The Story With the data layer (#87), GitHub CLI (#88), and TUI (#89) in place, we now need a way for users to view their roadmap items in the web viewer. The web UI already shows the decision graph - adding roadmap support creates a unified experience where users can see both their project planning (roadmap) and their decision history (graph) in one place. The key insight is that roadmap items and decision nodes are related - items can link to outcome nodes via `outcome_change_id`. The web view makes this relationship browsable. ## Decision Graph Context - **Goal**: #476 (Roadmap board system) - **UI Priority Decision**: #483 → #490 (CLI, TUI, and Web in parallel) - **Type Unification Decision**: Phase 8 (#502) - shared types across Rust/TypeScript ## What This PR Adds ### 1. RoadmapView Component (`web/src/views/RoadmapView.tsx`) A React component that renders roadmap items grouped by section: ```typescript // Section grouping with visual hierarchy {sections.map(section => (

{section}

{itemsBySection[section].map(item => ( ))}
))} ``` **Features**: - Items grouped by section (In Progress, Backlog, etc.) - Checkbox state visualization (☐/☑) - GitHub issue links (clickable badges) - Outcome node links (navigates to graph view) - Completion status indicators ### 2. Type Export System (`src/export.rs`) Adds roadmap items to the JSON export: ```rust #[derive(Serialize)] struct GraphExport { nodes: Vec, edges: Vec, roadmap_items: Vec, // NEW } ``` This extends `graph-data.json` to include roadmap data, used by both `deciduous serve` and `deciduous sync`. ### 3. TypeScript Type Generation (`web/src/types/generated/schema.ts`) Automatic generation via ts-rs ensures type safety: ```typescript export interface RoadmapItem { id: number; change_id: string; title: string; section?: string; checkbox_state: string; github_issue_number?: number; github_issue_state?: string; outcome_node_id?: number; outcome_change_id?: string; // ... } ``` ### 4. Completion Detection Logic Pure function matching TUI implementation: ```typescript function isItemComplete(item: RoadmapItem): boolean { const checkboxChecked = item.checkbox_state === 'checked'; const hasOutcome = !!item.outcome_change_id; const issueClosed = item.github_issue_state === 'closed'; return checkboxChecked && hasOutcome && issueClosed; } ``` Three-way completion: checkbox + outcome node + closed issue. ### 5. React Integration (`web/src/App.tsx`, `Layout.tsx`) - New `/roadmap` route - Navigation tab in sidebar - Hook into existing data fetching ## Architecture Diagram ``` ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ Web Viewer │ ├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ │ │ ┌─────────────┐ ┌─────────────┐ ┌─────────────┐ │ │ │ DAG View │ │ Timeline │ │ Roadmap │ │ │ │ (graph) │ │ View │ │ View │ NEW │ │ └──────┬──────┘ └──────┬──────┘ └──────┬──────┘ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ └───────────────────┴───────────────────┘ │ │ │ │ │ ┌────────┴────────┐ │ │ │ graph-data.json │ │ │ │ - nodes │ │ │ │ - edges │ │ │ │ - roadmap_items │ ← NEW │ │ └────────┬────────┘ │ └─────────────────────────────┼───────────────────────────────┘ │ │ `deciduous sync` or │ `deciduous serve` │ ┌─────────────────────────────┼───────────────────────────────┐ │ Rust Backend │ │ (src/export.rs) │ └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘ ``` ## Questions to Consider ### Before Merging 1. **Data freshness**: Should the web view auto-refresh roadmap data, or is the current 30-second graph refresh sufficient? 2. **Click-through navigation**: When clicking an outcome link, should it: - Navigate to the graph view with that node selected? - Open a modal with node details? - Something else? 3. **Empty state**: What should show when there are no roadmap items? Currently shows "No items found." ### Future Extensions 1. **Drag-and-drop reordering**: Could sections/items be reorderable in the web UI? 2. **Inline editing**: Should users be able to edit items directly in the web view? 3. **Filtering**: Add filters for completion status, section, linked/unlinked? 4. **Real-time sync**: WebSocket integration for live updates when markdown changes? ## Files Changed | File | Changes | |------|---------| | `web/src/views/RoadmapView.tsx` | NEW - Main roadmap component | | `web/src/App.tsx` | Add /roadmap route | | `web/src/components/Layout.tsx` | Add Roadmap navigation tab | | `src/export.rs` | Export roadmap_items in JSON | | `web/src/types/generated/schema.ts` | Add RoadmapItem type | | `web/src/hooks/useGraphData.ts` | Fetch roadmap data | ## What This PR Does NOT Include - Sync fixes (PR #5) - Decision graph data updates (PR #5) - Any CLI command changes (covered in PR #88) ## Test Plan - [ ] `cargo build --release` compiles - [ ] `cargo test` passes - [ ] `deciduous sync` includes roadmap_items in graph-data.json - [ ] `deciduous serve` shows roadmap tab in web UI - [ ] Clicking roadmap items with outcomes navigates to graph - [ ] GitHub issue badges link correctly - [ ] Items display correct completion status ## PR Chain ``` main └── #87 (Data Layer) └── #88 (GitHub + CLI) └── #89 (TUI View) └── #90 (Web View) ← YOU ARE HERE └── #91 (Polish) [coming next] ```

author: Bobby Nathan
message:
feat: add multi-user graph sync with diff/patch model

jj-inspired design for syncing decision graphs across multiple users:

Schema changes:
- Add change_id (UUID) column to decision_nodes for stable cross-db references
- Add from_change_id/to_change_id columns to decision_edges
- Auto-migration on database open for existing databases

New commands:
- deciduous diff export: Export nodes as JSON patch files
- deciduous diff apply: Apply patches to local database (idempotent)
- deciduous diff status: List patches in directory
- deciduous migrate: Manually run database migration

Patch format (JSON):
- version, author, branch, created_at, base_commit metadata
- nodes array with change_id, type, title, metadata
- edges array with from/to change_ids, edge_type, rationale

Workflow:
1. User creates nodes locally
2. Export: deciduous diff export --nodes 1-10 -o patches/feature.json
3. Commit patch file to git
4. Others pull and apply: deciduous diff apply patches/feature.json
5. Idempotent - same patch can be applied multiple times safely

See docs/MULTI_USER_SYNC.md for full design documentation.

author: Bobby Nathan
message:
Add React+TypeScript+Vite unified graph viewer (Phase A of Deciduous)

This is Phase A of extracting the decision graph tooling into a standalone
package called "deciduous". This commit adds a modern React web viewer that
combines all 4 existing graph views into a single tabbed interface.

## Decision Context (from graph nodes 99-107)

**Goal (node 99)**: Create Deciduous - extract decision graph tooling into
a standalone portable package that can be used in any project.

**Key Decision (node 101)**: Web viewer architecture
- Evaluated two options:
  - Option A (node 102): Vanilla JS + D3 - no build step, embed in binary
  - Option B (node 103): React + TypeScript + Vite - modern DX, type safety
- **Chose Option B** because TypeScript types can mirror Diesel ORM exactly,
  providing compile-time guarantees that frontend matches backend schemas.

**Decision (node 100)**: Include full Claude tooling in deciduous init
- Slash commands, CLAUDE.md workflow section, Makefile shortcuts
- This ensures projects using deciduous get the full decision-tracking workflow

## What's New

### web/ - React + TypeScript + Vite Application
- **4 Views Combined**: Chains, Timeline, Graph (D3 force), DAG (Dagre)
- **TypeScript Types**: Mirror Diesel ORM exactly (DecisionNode, DecisionEdge)
- **Shared Components**: Layout, DetailPanel, NodeBadge, TypeFilters
- **Graph Processing**: BFS chain building, session grouping, path tracing
- **Build**: Vite with React plugin, production bundle ~365KB

### Types Matching Diesel ORM
```typescript
// These match src/db.rs Diesel models exactly
type NodeType = 'goal' | 'decision' | 'option' | 'action' | 'outcome' | 'observation';
type NodeStatus = 'pending' | 'active' | 'completed' | 'rejected';
type EdgeType = 'leads_to' | 'requires' | 'chosen' | 'rejected' | 'blocks' | 'enables';
```

### Makefile Additions
- `make web` - Sync graph data and start dev server
- `make web-dev` - Start development server (http://localhost:3001)
- `make web-build` - Build production bundle
- `make web-typecheck` - Run TypeScript type checking
- `make web-sync` - Sync graph data to web/public/

### README Updates
- Documented web viewer commands
- Added note: Makefile is the primary entrypoint for Claude skills

## Files Added
- web/.gitignore - Excludes node_modules, dist, .vite
- web/package.json, tsconfig.json, vite.config.ts
- web/src/types/graph.ts - TypeScript types matching Diesel
- web/src/views/{ChainsView,TimelineView,GraphView,DagView}.tsx
- web/src/components/{Layout,DetailPanel,NodeBadge,TypeFilters}.tsx
- web/src/hooks/{useGraphData,useChains}.ts
- web/src/utils/{graphProcessing,colors}.ts

## Next Steps (Phases B-G)
- Phase B: Fork losselot to deciduous repository
- Phase C: Remove audio/WASM code, keep decision graph
- Phase D: Restructure CLI for deciduous commands
- Phase E: Add live viewing with file watcher and SSE
- Phase F: Implement deciduous init with Claude tooling
- Phase G: Create documentation site (GitHub Pages)

author: Bobby Grayson
message:
feat: GitHub Pages living museum site (#14)

* feat: Add GitHub Pages living museum site

A documentation site showcasing both the audio forensics tools and the
AI-assisted development methodology used to build this project.

Site structure:
- Landing page with quick start and four pillars overview
- Audio Analysis: CFCC, spectral analysis, detection explained
- Decision Graph: Tour of the real graph with screenshots
- Claude Tooling: Slash commands, context recovery, session continuity
- Development Story: Timeline, what didn't work, lessons learned

Demo includes:
- Real losselot.db with 17 nodes from actual development
- Interactive graph viewer loading real decision data
- Screenshots of the graph UI in action

The decision graph documents real choices made during development,
including the lo-fi detection algorithm decision (CFCC vs temporal
variance) and the site structure decision itself.

* feat: Add client-side WASM analyzer

Pure Rust FFT analysis compiled to WebAssembly - no JS fallback.
Runs the same 8192-sample windowed analysis as CLI: CFCC cliff
detection, cutoff variance, rolloff slope, ultrasonic energy.

- wasm-analyzer/: Rust crate with rustfft, wasm-bindgen
- docs/analyzer.html: Drag-drop UI, Web Audio API decoding
- GitHub Actions workflow builds WASM on deploy
